Properties of fresh catalysts Val6rie Labalme, Nathalie Benhamou, Nolven Guilhaume, Edouard Garbowski *, Michel Primet Laboratoire d'Application de la Chimie ~ l'Environnement (LACE), UMR CNRS-UCB Lyon 1, 43 Boulevard du 11 Novembre 1918, 69622 Villeurbanne Cedex, France Received 1 July 1995; revised 28 July 1995; accepted 28 July 1995 Abstract Platinum was deposited onto pure alumina as well as on alumina modified by addition of 7 and 15 wt.-% barium. The alumina hydroxyl groups were neutralized by barium addition and the surface of the modified support had a basic character. The introduction of barium decreased the accessible platinum area because of a sintering of the metal particles associated with a partial coverage of the platinum crystallites by barium containing species. In addition, the platinum surface atoms were electron-enriched. As a consequence the catalytic activity of alumina supported platinum was lowered in the presence of barium. Nevertheless, the turn-over numbers were not strongly modified by the barium additive, suggesting that the catalytic properties of accessible platinum atoms were not sen- sitive to the electronic effect induced by barium addition. Keywords: Catalytic combustion; Platinum; Alumina; Barium addition I. Introduction Catalytic combustion presents interesting properties when compared to conven- tional combustion in a flame. Lower temperature avoids any NOx formation, unbur- ned fuel is strongly reduced, whereas any air/fuel ratio can be used without loss of efficiency. Moreover a good design of catalyst and combustion process can be achieved without difficulties leading to a well performing burner. In the case of catalytic burners, a very high surface power is required in order to combine high power with small design. Consequently to high fuel feeding, high * Fax. This is not always safe for the catalyst's life, that has to be highly resistant. Catalysts able to perform combustion are divided into two groups: noble metals for which reaction may start at a temperature as low as room temperature, and transition metal oxides which are less efficient, but also more resistant towards high temperatures. Noble metal based catalysts, although much more active, suffer from their sen- sitivity towards high temperature: the presence of both water vapour and high temperature is critical for support and metal stability, y-A1203 is very often used as a support for combustion catalysts. However, this transition alumina is trans- formed into the more stable c~-structure at high temperature ( > 1000), which has a very low surface area [ 1,2] : consequently loss of performance due to simul- taneous sintering of the active phase occurs. Addition of promoters can be very useful in stabilizing the support. Lanthanum and silicon are efficient to stabilize alumina towards sintering [3-6]: it may be hoped that the active phase may be stabilized as well. On the other hand alumina is able to incorporate alkaline, alkaline-earth and rare- earth oxides to form new phases. They are referred to as hexaaluminate or are also named/3-alumina, because their structure corresponds to the formula MO. 6A1203 in the case of alkaline-earth oxides. Such double oxides have shown exceptional thermal stability, keeping a surface area of about 15 m2/g at 1400 [7-9]. The scope of this work is to investigate the effect of barium introduction upon the physicochemical and catalytic properties of a classical Pt/AI203 catalyst in the combustion of n-butane. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalysts preparation Three catalysts containing 2.5 wt.-% platinum, deposited on a commercial alu- mina (Oxid C, from Degussa), have been prepared. The support is a flame alumina, almost amorphous, the only phase detected by X-ray diffraction being the 6-form. It is constituted of small spheres without any porous volume, leading to an area of 100 m2/g. It contains some chlorine ions (0.5%) due to its preparation mode. The platinum precursor was hexachloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtC166H20). Reference catalyst Pt/Al20 3 Alumina was suspended into a solution of the required amount of H2PtC166H20 in acetone. The solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the solid was dried at 120, then crushed and calcined under flowing air (6 1 h- ~) at 500 for two hours in order to decompose the hexachloroplatinic acid. Platinum was then reduced under hydrogen at 500 (6 1 h- ~) for two hours. V. Labalme et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 133 (1995) 351-366 353 Barium-loaded catalysts Alumina was suspended in a solution of barium acetate dissolved in water. Water was removed under reduced pressure, and the solid was dried overnight at 120, then crushed. This powder was suspended again into a solution of hexachloropla- tinic acid in acetone. This procedure allows the deposition of H2PtC16" 6H20 on the barium acetate-loaded alumina, without allowing a redissolution of the barium salt during the second impregnation step, as barium acetate is not soluble in acetone. The powder was calcined under air, then reduced by H2, under the same conditions as the reference catalyst. Two different barium loadings of either 10 or 20% BaO in weight were chosen. The corresponding catalysts will be noted as Pt/AI203, Pt/Ba*AI203 and Pt/ Ba* * A1203 where * and * * stand for low and high BaO loadings, respectively. The catalysts were sieved to a particle size smaller than 100/.~m prior to use. 2.2. Physicochemical characterizations Chemical analysis allowed the determination of platinum, barium and residual chlorine contents. The solids were dissolved in a mixture of HF + HC1 + HNO3 solution for analysis by atomic absorption spectroscopy. BET areas were measured by nitrogen adsorption at - 196 on samples pre- viously evacuated under vacuum ( 10-s Torr) at 300 for 2 h. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a D 500 Siemens diffractometer using monochromatized Cu Ko~ radiation. The patterns were recorded from 3 to 7020 with a scan rate of 1.2min-~. The patterns were compared with the ICDD reference data file for phase identification. The percentage of accessible platinum area was deduced from nJo2 titrations and from CO irreversible adsorption. In each case, subtraction of reversible adsorp- tion and extrapolation to zero pressure allowed to determine the dispersion of metallic phase. Infrared experiments were performed using a FTIR spectrometer (IFS 110 from Bruker, resolution 4 cm- ~ ). Adsorption of carbon monoxide on the metal was used to study the modification in the adsorption properties of platinum induced by the barium oxide. Adsorption of carbon dioxide on alumina revealed the modification in the acido-basic character of the support. The samples were pressed in order to obtain a thin disk of known weight, which was introduced in a cell and reduced in- situ by hydrogen at 500 overnight. After desorption of chemisorbed hydrogen at 500, the samples were cooled down to room temperature. CO or CO2 were introduced at room temperature, then evacuated under vacuum. In the case of CO2, evacuation was pursued at increasing temperatures up to 200. The samples were analyzed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Jeol 100 CX). The powder was ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol. Then a drop of the suspension was deposited on copper grid. 354 V. Labalme et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 133 (1995) 351-366 2.3. Catalytic activity measurements The combustion of butane is strongly exothermic when expressed as energy evolved per mole of hydrocarbon (2880 kJ/mol). Consequently no isothermal test can be performed using a reactor highly loaded with catalyst and a gas mixture containing too much fuel. Both fuel and catalyst should be diluted. 20 mg of catalyst were diluted in 100 mg of SiC having roughly the same granulometry (particle size: 45 to 100/zm). The powder was placed into a quartz microreactor allowing a thin catalytic bed (1 mm height, 18 mm diameter). The feedstream consisted in 0.33 vol.-% n-butane, 2.56 vol.-% oxygen and balance nitrogen. The oxygen excess ( = 20%) avoids any coke deposition. The total flow- rate was 18.6 1 h-1, corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 400 000 h- 1 relative to the catalyst. All gases were dehydrated over a molecular sieve prior use. Conversion was expressed as the ratio of CO and CO2 produced upon the total gas present in the exhaust (CO + CO2 + 4 * C4H1o) taken into account the stoichi- ometry of the reaction. Selectivity was defined as the ratio of CO2 produced upon the (CO + CO2) total produced. The product distribution is expressed as the partial pressure of each component, the reaction being performed at atmospheric pressure. Knowing the dispersion of the metallic phase, the Turn-Over Number (TON) can be calculated when it is defined as the r/D ratio where 'r' stands for the rate of reaction (expressed as mole of butane converted per hour and per mole of Pt) and 'D' stands for the dispersion of metallic phase. Prior to reaction, the prereduced catalysts were heated at 500 under nitrogen, then reduced again by hydrogen at 500 for one hour. The temperature was lowered to 150 under H2, and the reactor was purged by nitrogen for 15 min. Feed containing fuel was then admitted and activity was measured from 150 up to 500, by steps of 10, for 90 min at each temperature. This long time was necessary to reach steady-state conditions and to insure that no deactivation occurred during the test. These first measurements performed with fresh catalysts are hereafter referred as 'State I'. The catalysts were kept at 500 for one night at total butane conversion. The reactor was then purged with nitrogen and cooled down to 150. Feed was further admitted and the conversion was measured again between 150 and 500. This second measurement will be referred as 'State II' in the discussion. 3. Results 3.1. BET areas The results of nitrogen adsorption measurements on the fresh catalysts are reported in Table 2. The specific surface area (SSA) of catalyst Pt/AI203 is not lowered compared to that of alumina alone. The SSA of Ba-containing catalysts decrease as the loading of BaO increases. In fact it should not be forgotten that barium is a heavy element: introduction of 8.5 or 17.2% BaO, considering that the surface is developed by alumina only, is supposed to decrease the specific area of the samples. However, some weak lines could be attributed to the most intense diffraction lines of BaCO3 in the spectra of catalyst Pt/Ba* *A1203. After evacuation under vacuum at room temperature for 20 rain, only the first band at 2070 cm- remains with almost the same intensity. Catalytic activi~ Results of catalytic activity for n-butane combustion are illustrated by Figs. 5 and 6, along with Table 4 where apparent activation energies and Tso temperatures, corresponding to 50% butane conversion, are reported. The three catalysts are 100% selective in CO2, whatever the temperature. Due to the high butane conversion levels obtained with increasing temperature a model of integral plug-flow reactor was used. Thus assuming an irreversible reaction, the In (x/1 -x) function was supposed to be linear versus 1/T: In(x/1 -x) = - E/RT+ lnko + lnz where x, E, ko and ~- stand for conversion, apparent activation energy, rate constant and residence time, respectively. Up to 70% conversion the experimental data fit the linear plot In (x/1 -x) versus 1/T allowing apparent energy calculation. Thus below 70% conversion mass transport limitation does not occur. Consequently apparent activation energy determinations seem to be confident and are within an error of ca. 4 to 5 kJ/mol. At higher conversion diffusional limitations were evi- denced by a strong lowering in the Arrhenius plot (factor of ca. 2). The effect of barium on the conversion of butane for fresh catalysts in State I is shown in Fig. 5: introduction of Ba leads to less active catalysts, and the higher the loading, the lower the activity. However the activities of the two Ba-containing catalysts are not very different at low conversions. This is in accordance with dispersions deduced from chemisorption measurements, as the dispersion of plat- inum is the same in Pt/Ba*AI203 and Pt/Ba**AlzO3. This is also true when comparing Pt/A1203 and Pt/Ba* A1203: activity as well as platinum dispersion are about 3 times higher for Pt/A1203. Discussion The introduction of barium on a Pt/A1203 catalyst has a strong influence on the surface and catalytic properties, both being related. 4.1. Effect of barium on the support properties The introduction of Ba leads to a decrease in the specific surface areas of the catalysts. Calcination at 500 to decompose the barium acetate into BaO does not induce any phase transformation of the alumina. Thus the loss of specific surface area could be associated with some sintering process, or some soldering of alumina particles via BaO bridges. XRD does not allow to detect any BaO phase (though some small diffraction lines could be tentatively assigned to BaCO3, which may be formed by reaction of BaO with atmospheric CO2). Barium oxide is thus expected to be well dispersed, in a bidimensional network. In the same sense, infrared spectroscopy of catalysts after evacuation at 500 shows the disappearance of alumina OH superficial groups. These observations suggest that the alumina surface is totally covered by BaO. A simple calculation allows the determination of the barium content necessary for the neutralization of the alumina hydroxyl groups. The following hypotheses have been made: (i) the amount of alumina hydroxyl groups was estimated not to exceed 10 OH/nm2, (ii) one barium atom was responsible for the neutralization of two surface OH groups. According to such hypotheses, the barium content needed for the full coverage of the alumina surface was found to be ca. 9.8 wt.-% Ba, a value close to the Ba content of the less barium loaded catalyst. FTIR study of CO2 adsorbed on the support reveals the properties of superficial OH groups. The spectrum of CO2 adsorbed onto Pt/AI203 shows the characteristic bands of hydrogen carbonate ions. This behaviour of the surface of alumina is well known and well documented. When CO2 was adsorbed on Pt/Ba* AlzO3, no hydro- gen carbonates are formed, but instead monodendate carbonate ions are observed, which correspond to carbonates formed with superficial BaO and which confirms V. Labalme et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 133 (1995) 351-366 363 the covering of alumina by BaO. These species are stable when the sample was desorbed at 200. It should be remembered that alkaline-earth carbonates are particularly thermally stable. For the high Ba-loaded solid Pt/Ba* *A1203, the presence of the additional band at 1450 cm-1, which can be attributed to bidentate carbonate ions i.e. to bulk BaCO3, also suggests the presence of thicker zones of BaO, as a thin layer or monolayer of BaO could not give bulk barium carbonate. The support consists now in a BaO layer supported onto alumina, this layer being of various thickness as shown by STEM analysis of the surface. 4.2. Effect of barium on the physicochemical properties of platinum The modification in the acido-basic properties of the doped supports is expected to induce different properties of platinum: as far as accessible metallic area is concerned, introduction of barium leads to metal modifications. For both barium- containing samples, whatever the loading, the accessible metallic area is greatly reduced. Surprisingly, the metallic area is the same whatever the BaO loading. One explanation could be that the decrease of accessible metallic area is not to be associated with a sintering of Pt particles, but with the partial covering of these particles by BaO, despite the fact that during the second impregnation step care was taken to avoid any redissolution of the barium acetate by the use of acetone as solvent for H2PtC16.6H20. The X-ray diffraction pattern of reference catalyst Pt/A1203 presents the most intense lines corresponding to the metal and t~-A1203. The spectrum is very noisy: this is related to the structure of alumina which is highly amorphous, the only crystallized phase being the 6 structure. For the barium-containing samples, the diffraction lines due to alumina or platinum seem to be of lower intensity compared to the pattern of Pt/A1203. The covering of metal particles and alumina by BaO could again explain this. FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed CO reveals the modification of platinum prop- erties in the presence of BaO. Increasing the barium loading leads to a downward frequency shift of the uCO band corresponding to linearly bonded CO, together with a decrease of its intensity. New bands are also observed in the presence of BaO, which can be attributed to new CO species bonded to platinum in strong interaction with barium, and to CO bridging platinum and barium. This suggests that the metallic surface available for adsorbing CO is reduced due to partial covering by BaO. This is in accordance with the chemisorption measurements: less H2 or CO is now irreversibly adsorbed at room temperature. However, electron microscopy also shows a slight sintering of Pt particles for Ba-loaded catalysts, as the average particle diameters are somewhat larger than those in Pt/A1203. It can be concluded that the introduction of barium leads to a decrease of the accessible metallic area, both by sintering of Pt particles and by their partial covering by barium-containing species. 364 V. Labalme et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 133 (1995) 351-366 4.3. Influence of barium on the catalytic properties The introduction of barium has a strong influence on the catalytic properties in the combustion of butane: high and low barium loadings lead in any case to less active catalysts. Comparison of activities at low conversion (at 240) show that the conversion is about 3 times higher for Pt/A1203 than for the two Ba-containing catalysts. This is in accordance with the lower accessible metallic areas of the Ba- containing samples. Activity is mainly reduced by a geometrical factor due to covering of metallic particles by B aO. However, the activation energies (Table 4) are slightly lower in the case of the two Ba-containing catalysts (in State I) than for Pt/A1203. Here the decrease in Ea cannot compensate the decrease in the number of active sites, within the temperature range studied here: the whole activity is lowered and shifted towards high temperature. However the calculated turn-over numbers at 230 and 250 (Table 5) do not allow to draw any definite conclu- sion about the effect of BaO upon the catalytic properties of platinum. Catalysts in State II, having operated at 100% conversion at 500 for one night, show evident activation: for reference catalyst Pt/A1203 activation is particularly clear because the Tso is shifted by 44 whereas activation energy is decreased by 24 kJ/mol. At low conversion, i.e. at 200, comparison of activities reveals that the catalyst in State II is about twelve times more active. This activation under reactants has already been reported for combustion catalysts based on platinum or palladium deposited on alumina [ 18-23 ]. It occurs via a reconstruction of the metal particles under reactants, together with a sintering of the metal: exposed surface active atoms are fewer after the test, but they are more efficient. The elimination of residual chloride ions under the stream could also be an explanation of the activation of the catalysts [ 24,25 ]. The conditions of the tests (20 mg catalyst diluted in 100 mg SiC) did not allow to check the amount of C1 in State II samples. However, studies on palladium catalysts used in combustion reactions [ 26] have shown that activation occurs even when the palladium precursor used was palladium acetyla- cetonate, which contains no chlorine, deposited on chlorine-free alumina. Activa- tion of catalysts frequently observed in the case of hydrocarbon combustion does not only depend upon the removal of chlorine bonded to metal particles. In the present study an activation was observed onto barium-containing samples as well as onto barium-free solids. Thus the activation cannot be correlated with an inter- action between chlorine and Ba-containing species. The Ba-containing catalysts are also activated in State II, though this effect is less pronounced than in the case of Pt/AI203. At low conversions, the Pt/Ba*AI203 catalyst is about two times more active in State II. In this case, where alumina is covered by BaO, activation is not easy to explain because the interaction between alumina and platinum, which is supposed to promote the metal particle reconstruc- tion, is now reduced. The activation energy is less lowered between States I and II in the case of Pt/Ba*A1203 ( - 11 kJ/mol) than for Pt/A1203 ( - 24 kJ/mol), and is not modified for Pt/Ba* * A1203 ( + 3 kJ/mol). This means that there is no change K Labalme et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 133 (1995) 351-366 365 in the surface atom properties. Secondly the shift of the Tso temperatures are the same ( - 17 and - 20 for Pt/Ba*A1203 and Pt/Ba* *A1203 respectively), and less pronounced than for Pt/A1203 ( - 44). This suggests that the activation may consist in a simple recovering of surface Pt atoms which were previously encap- sulated or covered by BaO, by extraction of the metal particles from the BaO layer during the combustion process. According to the gain in activity, a slight sintering of BaO apart from Pt is sufficient to give bare atoms again. If a true reconstruction does occur, it should be very limited in order to increase the activity by a factor of 2. 5. Conclusion Introduction of barium onto an alumina prior to supporting platinum has several effects. For the support, most of the alumina hydroxyl groups have been neutralized by BaO. This layer is not homogeneous in thickness, as some zone are covered by several unit cells. Surface appears now basic due to presence of strongly electron- donating oxygen atoms. As far as platinum is concemed, the presence of a basic support modifies the electron properties of the metal. It is electron-enriched, whereas the accessible metallic area is reduced. The presence of barium oxide is detrimental to the catalytic activity in butane combustion, suggesting a partial covering of platinum by barium oxide. Activation of catalysts under reactants is very limited due probably to a recovering of some Pt atoms previously covered by BaO. As such an introduction of Ba seems not very worthwhile if no other gain in activity or stability is evidenced. This will be the aim of the second part of this work [ 27 ], which will describe the influence of BaO on the thermal stability of these catalysts. (+33) 78941995. Platinum was deposited onto pure alumina as well as on alumina modified by addition of 7 and 15 wt.-% barium. The alumina hydroxyl groups were neutralized by barium addition and the surface of the modified support had a basic character. The introduction of barium decreased the accessible platinum area because of a sintering of the metal particles associated with a partial coverage of the platinum crystallites by barium containing species. In addition, the platinum surface atoms were electron-enriched. As a consequence the catalytic activity of alumina supported platinum was lowered in the presence of barium.
